title: METABODY: Body Metacognition, Mentalization and Metamorphosis
descriptions:
The proposed project, METABODY, aims to investigate the concept of Body Imagining as a dynamic inference process rather than a fixed representation in the brain. This novel approach seeks to understand the interplay between prior beliefs and new information in shaping body image phenomena in modern society. Specifically, METABODY will explore the metacognitive level of these inferences, hypothesizing that body image disturbances stem not only from biases in perceiving one's body, but also in evaluating the reliability of these perceptions in different contexts.

Through three empirical work-packages, METABODY will study how individuals balance their embodied experience with external and social perspectives, as well as future and ideal body perspectives. By examining Body Metacognition, Body Mentalizing, and Body Decision Making, the project will shed light on the complex processes involved in negotiating the balance between the invariance and invention of our identity in a world where changing the body is increasingly seen as a means of self-transformation.

Overall, METABODY offers an innovative and timely exploration of how we navigate the complex interplay between our internal body image and external influences in shaping our sense of self in a society where body modification is prevalent.

**Description:**

We live in a socio-economic world that affords us with increasing options and technologies to control and present our bodily appearance to others, including by managing our eating habits, or by digital and even surgical body modification. These proliferating phenomena raise the age-old question of how we negotiate the balance between the invariance and invention of our identity. Addressing this question in relation to modern body image phenomena requires a radical new way of studying the concept of body image. METABODY proposes the novel concept of Body Imagining to capture the idea that our body image is not a fixed representation in the brain, but rather a dynamic inference based on prior expectations and new information. Studying the balance between prior beliefs and new information could thus hold the key to understanding modern body image phenomena. Moreover, existing studies have failed to investigate the metacognitive level of these inferences. METABODY will test the novel hypothesis that body image disturbances are not the result of biases merely in the 1st order ability to perceive oneâ€™s body, but also in the 2nd order ability to evaluate the reliability of these perceptions in given contexts. Specifically, three empirical work-packages will study how individuals balance their own embodied experience against: (1) external perspectives on the body during multisensory perception (Body Metacognition), (2) social perspectives during interpersonal encounters (Body Mentalizing) and (3) future and ideal body perspectives during decisions about body modification options with uncertain outcome (Body Decision Making). Ultimately, METABODY will address in innovative ways the timely question of how we negotiate the balance between the invariance and invention of our identity in a time when changing the body is offered as an easy way to change the self.
